Think Locally, Act Globally:
Federated Learning with Local and Global Representations

Paul Pu Liang1âˆ— Terrance Liu1âˆ— Liu Ziyin2 Nicholas B. Allen3 Randy P. Auerbach4 David Brent5 Ruslan Salakhutdinov1 Louis-Philippe Morency1
1School of Computer Science Carnegie Mellon University
2Department of Physics University of Tokyo
3Department of Psychology University of Oregon
4Department of Psychiatry Columbia University
5Department of Psychiatry University of Pittsburgh
{pliang,terrancl,morency}@cs.cmu.edu
Abstract

Federated learning is a method of training models on private data distributed over multiple devices. To keep device data private, the global model is trained by only communicating parameters and updates which poses scalability challenges for large models. To this end, we propose a new federated learning algorithm that jointly learns compact local representations on each device and a global model across all devices. As a result, the global model can be smaller since it only operates on local representations, reducing the number of communicated parameters. Theoretically, we provide a generalization analysis which shows that a combination of local and global models reduces both variance in the data as well as variance across device distributions. Empirically, we demonstrate that local models enable communication-efficient training while retaining performance. We also evaluate on the task of personalized mood prediction from real-world mobile data where privacy is key. Finally, local models handle heterogeneous data from new devices, and learn fair representations that obfuscate protected attributes such as race, age, and gender.â€ â€ âˆ—first two authors contributed equally.

1 Introduction

Federated learning is an emerging research paradigm to train machine learning models on private data distributed in a potentially non-i.i.d. setting over multiple devicesÂ [38]. A key challenge involves keeping private all the data on each device by training a global model only via communication of parameter updates to each device. This relies on the global model being sufficiently compact so that the parameters and updates can be sent efficiently over existing communication channels such as wireless networksÂ [44]. However, the recent demands in larger models pose a challenge for deploying federated learning on real-world tasks. In this paper, we propose a new federated learning algorithm, Local Global Federated AveragingÂ (LG-FedAvg), which jointly learns compact local representations on each device and a global model across all devices. We perform a generalization analysis of federated learning which shows that a combination of local and global models reduces both variance in the data as well as variance across device distributions, which is more optimal than either extreme. To support our theoretical analysis, we perform a wide range of experiments that suggest local representation learning is beneficial for the following reasons:

1) Efficiency: Having local models extract useful, lower-dimensional representations means that the global model now requires fewer number of parameters, thereby reducing the number of parameters and updates that need to be communicated to and from the global model as well as the bottleneck in terms of communication cost. Our proposed method also maintains performance on publicly available datasets spanning image recognition (MNIST, CIFAR) and multimodal learning (VQA).

2) Heterogeneity: Real-world data is often heterogeneous (coming from different sources). A new device could contain sources of data that have never been observed before during training, such as images of a different domain or different texting styles on personalized mobile devices. Local representations allow us to process new device data using specialized encoders depending on their source modalitiesÂ [2] instead of using a single global model that might not generalize to new modalities and distributionsÂ [41]. We show that our model learns personalized mood predictors from real-world private mobile data and better deals with heterogeneous data never seen during training.

3) Fairness: Real-world data often contains sensitive attributes and recent work has shown that it is possible to recover these attributes from data representations without access to the data itselfÂ [4]. We show that local models can be modified to learn fair representations that obfuscate protected attributes such as race, age, and gender, a feature crucial to preserving the privacy of on-device data.

2 Related Work

Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networksÂ [38] at a large scaleÂ [5], over multiple sources of heterogeneous dataÂ [30], and over multiple learning objectivesÂ [50]. Recent methods aim to improve the efficiency of federated learningÂ [7], perform learning in a one-shot settingÂ [20], propose realistic benchmarksÂ [8], and reduce the data mismatch between local and global data distributionsÂ [41]. While several specific algorithms have been proposed for heterogeneous data, LG-FedAvgÂ is a more general framework that can handle heterogeneous data from new devices, reduce communication complexity, and ensure fair representation learning. We compare with these existing baselines and show that LG-FedAvgÂ outperforms them in heterogeneous settings.

Distributed Learning is a related field with similarities and key differences: while both study the theory and practice involving the partition of data and aggregation of updatesÂ [3, 52], federated learning is additionally concerned with data that is private and distributed in a non-i.i.d. fashion. Recent work has improved communication efficiency by sparsifying the data and modelÂ [54], developing efficient gradient methodsÂ [55, 12], and compressing the updatesÂ [53]. These compression techniques are complementary to our approach and can be applied to our local and global models.

Representation Learning involves learning features from data for generative and discriminative tasks. A recent focus has been on learning fair representationsÂ [57], including using adversarial trainingÂ [19] to learn representations that are not informative of private attributesÂ [17, 9] such as demographicsÂ [15] and genderÂ [56]. A related line of research is differential privacy which constraints statistical databases to limit the privacy impact on individuals whose information is in the databaseÂ [13, 14]. Our approach extends recent advances in adapting federated learning for heterogeneous data and fairness. LG-FedAvgÂ is a general framework that can handle heterogeneous data from new devices, reduce communication complexity, and ensure fair representation learning.

3 Local Global Federated Averaging

At a high level, LG-FedAvgÂ combines local representation learning with global model learning in an end-to-end manner. Each local device learns to extract higher-level representations from raw data before a global model operates on the representations (rather than raw data) from all devices. An overview of LG-FedAvgÂ is shown in FigureÂ 1. The local and global learning procedures are designed to be complementary: local representation learning aims to extract high level, compact features important for prediction, thereby allowing the global model to save parameters by operating only on lower dimensional representations. At the same time, the global model objective ensures that the global model must be able to classify data from all devices, thereby ensuring that the local representations are general enough instead of overfitting to the subset of data on each device. We begin by describing how local (Â§3.1) and global (Â§3.2) learning is performed. We then detail one example of adversarial local learning to learn fair local representations (AppendixÂ B.1).

3.2 Global Aggregation

Learning this joint global model gğ‘”g across all devices requires the aggregation of global parameter updates from each device. At each iteration tğ‘¡t of global model training, the server sends a copy of the global model parameters Î¸gâ€‹(t)superscriptğœƒğ‘”ğ‘¡\theta^{g(t)} to each device which we now label as Î¸mgâ€‹(t)superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘”ğ‘¡\theta_{m}^{g(t)} to represent the asynchronous updates made to each local copy. We can compute the overall loss on device mğ‘šm:

(1)

The loss is a function of both the local and global model parameters (Î¸mâ„“superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“\theta_{m}^{\ell} and Î¸mgsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘”\theta_{m}^{g} respectively) so both can be updated in an end-to-end manner. We argue that this synchronizes the training of the local models: while local models can flexibly fit the small amounts of data on their device, objectiveÂ 1 acts as a regularizer to synchronize the local representations learned from all devices. Each local model cannot overfit to local data because otherwise, the joint global model would not be able to simultaneously predict from all local representations and the value of objectiveÂ 1 would be high.

The local model parameters Î¸mâ„“superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“\theta_{m}^{\ell} are updated by gradient-based methods in a straightforward manner. The global model parameters on device mğ‘šm, Î¸mgâ€‹(t)superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘”ğ‘¡\theta_{m}^{g(t)}, are also asynchronously updated to Î¸mgâ€‹(t+1)superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘”ğ‘¡1\theta_{m}^{g(t+1)} using gradient-based methods. After these local updates, each device now returns the updated global parameters Î¸mgâ€‹(t+1)superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘”ğ‘¡1\theta_{m}^{g(t+1)} back to the server which aggregates these updates using a weighted average of the fraction of data points in each device, Î¸gâ€‹(t+1)=âˆ‘m=1MNmNâ€‹Î¸mgâ€‹(t+1)superscriptğœƒğ‘”ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğœƒğ‘”ğ‘¡1ğ‘š\theta^{g(t+1)}=\sum_{m=1}^{M}\frac{N_{m}}{N}\theta^{g(t+1)}_{m}Â [38]. The overall training procedure is shown in AlgorithmÂ 1. Communication only happens when training the global model, which as we will show in our experiments, can be small given good local representations.

3.3 Inference at Test Time

Given a new test sample ğ±â€²superscriptğ±â€²\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, how do we know which trained local model â„“mâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptâ„“ğ‘š\ell^{*}_{m} fits ğ±â€²superscriptğ±â€²\mathbf{x}^{\prime} best? We consider two settings: (1) Local Test where we know which device the test data belongs to (e.g. training a personalized text completer). Using that local model works best for best match between train and test distributions. (2) New Test where it is possible to have a new device during testing with new data distributions. To address the new device, we view each local model as trained on a different view of the global data distribution. We pass ğ±â€²superscriptğ±â€²\mathbf{x}^{\prime} through all trained local models â„“mâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptâ„“ğ‘š\ell^{*}_{m} and ensemble the outputs.

4 Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we provide a theoretical analysis of using local and global models for federated learning. We show that 1) purely local models do not suffer from device variance but suffer from data variance, 2) the opposite holds true for purely global models, and 3) having both local and global models achieves a balance between both desiderata. All detailed proofs can be found in AppendixÂ A. The link between the analysis and LG-FedAvgÂ for deep networks is discussed at the end of the section and verified via comprehensive experiments in Â§Â 5.1.

We assume a student-teacher settingÂ [25, 21], where the goal is to train a network fğ®^subscriptğ‘“^ğ®f_{\hat{\mathbf{u}}} with weights ğ®^âˆˆâ„d^ğ®superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\hat{\mathbf{u}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} on a task whose target is produced by a teacher network fğ®subscriptğ‘“ğ®f_{\mathbf{u}} (i.e. the realizability assumption). We assume that the targets are generated from a linear model. While simple in setup, its behavior is rich and has proved insightful in the understanding of nonlinear models as wellÂ [40, 39, 21]. To adapt this setting for federated learning, we assume that all device share some underlying structure (e.g. natural syntactic and semantic structures in text) while also displaying personalization across users (e.g. personalized vocabularies and writing styles). Mathematically, this involves a global feature vector ğ¯ğ¯\mathbf{v} that represents shared features across devices as well as local features ğ«msubscriptğ«ğ‘š\mathbf{r}_{m} that represent differences across devices. The labels on device mğ‘šm are generated by a local teacher with weights ğ®m=ğ¯+ğ«mâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ®ğ‘šğ¯subscriptğ«ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{u}_{m}=\mathbf{v}+\mathbf{r}_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. Ï2superscriptğœŒ2\rho^{2} represents device variance: with higher Ï2superscriptğœŒ2\rho^{2}, the local features differ more representing more personalized targets across devices. Analysis of local and global baselines: We first analyze two baselines for federated learning. The first method learns local models on each deviceÂ [50]: fâ„“â€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^,ğ®^m)=fâ€‹(ğ±;ğ®^m)=ğ®^mâŠ¤â€‹ğ±subscriptğ‘“â„“ğ±^ğ¯subscript^ğ®ğ‘šğ‘“ğ±subscript^ğ®ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscript^ğ®ğ‘štopğ±f_{\ell}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}},\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m})=f(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m})=\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m}^{\top}\mathbf{x}.

Proposition 2.

The generalization error â„°â€‹(fâ„“)â„°subscriptğ‘“â„“\mathcal{E}(f_{\ell}) of local model fâ„“â€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^,ğ®^m)subscriptğ‘“â„“ğ±^ğ¯subscript^ğ®ğ‘šf_{\ell}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}},\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m}) is dNâ€‹Ïƒ2ğ‘‘ğ‘superscriptğœ2\frac{d}{N}\sigma^{2}.

This shows that local models only control data variance at a rate of d/Nğ‘‘ğ‘d/{N} since they are only updated using local device data which may be limited in number and vary highly (both in quality and quantity) across devices. However, local models do not suffer from device variance.

The second method updates a joint global model (i.e. vanilla federated learning;Â [38]), which is equivalent to setting Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0, i.e. fgâ€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^,ğ®^m)=fâ€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^)=ğ¯^âŠ¤â€‹ğ±subscriptğ‘“ğ‘”ğ±^ğ¯subscript^ğ®ğ‘šğ‘“ğ±^ğ¯superscript^ğ¯topğ±f_{g}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}},\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m})=f(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}})=\hat{\mathbf{v}}^{\top}\mathbf{x}. Its generalization error â„°â€‹(fg)â„°subscriptğ‘“ğ‘”\mathcal{E}(f_{g}) is:

Proposition 3.

The generalization error â„°â€‹(fg)â„°subscriptğ‘“ğ‘”\mathcal{E}(f_{g}) of the global model fgâ€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^,ğ®^m)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘”ğ±^ğ¯subscript^ğ®ğ‘šf_{g}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}},\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m}) is Mâˆ’1Mâ€‹Ï2+dMâ€‹Nâ€‹Ïƒ2ğ‘€1ğ‘€superscriptğœŒ2ğ‘‘ğ‘€ğ‘superscriptğœ2\frac{M-1}{M}\rho^{2}+\frac{d}{MN}\sigma^{2}.

Global models can control for data variance (Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}) at a rate of d/(Mâ€‹N)ğ‘‘ğ‘€ğ‘d/(MN), decreasing with the total number of datapoints across all devices (since global parameters are updated using data across all devices), which is better than the rate for local models. However, it suffers from an extra Oâ€‹(Ï2)ğ‘‚superscriptğœŒ2O(\rho^{2}) term representing device variance so one global model is unable to account for very different devices.

Analysis of LG-FedAvg: Given that the above baselines achieve different generalization errors, one should be able to interpolate between the two methods to find the optimal tradeoff point. Therefore, our method defines an Î±âˆ’limit-fromğ›¼\alpha-interpolation between the global and local models, fÎ±â€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^,ğ®^m)=Î±â€‹fâ„“â€‹(ğ±;ğ®^m)+(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹fgâ€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^)subscriptğ‘“ğ›¼ğ±^ğ¯subscript^ğ®ğ‘šğ›¼subscriptğ‘“â„“ğ±subscript^ğ®ğ‘š1ğ›¼subscriptğ‘“ğ‘”ğ±^ğ¯f_{\alpha}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}},\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m})=\alpha f_{\ell}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m})+(1-\alpha)f_{g}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}}), where Î±âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1]. The generalization error, â„°â€‹(fÎ±)â„°subscriptğ‘“ğ›¼\mathcal{E}(f_{\alpha}) is:

Theorem 2.

The generalization error â„°â€‹(fÎ±)â„°subscriptğ‘“ğ›¼\mathcal{E}(f_{\alpha}) is Î±2â€‹dNâ€‹Ïƒ2+(1âˆ’Î±)2â€‹Mâˆ’1Mâ€‹Ï2+(1âˆ’Î±2)â€‹dMâ€‹Nâ€‹Ïƒ2superscriptğ›¼2ğ‘‘ğ‘superscriptğœ2superscript1ğ›¼2ğ‘€1ğ‘€superscriptğœŒ21superscriptğ›¼2ğ‘‘ğ‘€ğ‘superscriptğœ2\alpha^{2}\frac{d}{N}\sigma^{2}+(1-\alpha)^{2}\frac{M-1}{M}\rho^{2}+(1-\alpha^{2})\frac{d}{MN}\sigma^{2}.

Corollary 1.

The optimal Î±âˆ—superscriptğ›¼\alpha^{*} minimizing â„°â€‹(fÎ±)â„°subscriptğ‘“ğ›¼\mathcal{E}(f_{\alpha}) is Î±âˆ—=Ï2Ï2+dNâ€‹Ïƒ2superscriptğ›¼superscriptğœŒ2superscriptğœŒ2ğ‘‘ğ‘superscriptğœ2\alpha^{*}=\frac{\rho^{2}}{\rho^{2}+\frac{d}{N}\sigma^{2}}. When Ï2,Ïƒ2>0superscriptğœŒ2superscriptğœ20\rho^{2},\ \sigma^{2}>0, we have that â„°â€‹(fÎ±âˆ—)<â„°â€‹(fâ„“)â„°subscriptğ‘“superscriptğ›¼â„°subscriptğ‘“â„“\mathcal{E}(f_{\alpha^{*}})<\mathcal{E}(f_{\ell}) and â„°â€‹(fÎ±âˆ—)<â„°â€‹(fg)â„°subscriptğ‘“superscriptğ›¼â„°subscriptğ‘“ğ‘”\mathcal{E}(f_{\alpha^{*}})<\mathcal{E}(f_{g}), a generalization error better than local or global extremes.

This shows that using an ensemble of local and global models reduces both data variance and device variance. When Ï2superscriptğœŒ2\rho^{2} is large (high device variance), one should prioritize local models that better model the local data distributions (larger Î±âˆ—superscriptğ›¼\alpha^{*}). Conversely, when Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is large (high data variance), one should prioritize a global model (smaller Î±âˆ—superscriptğ›¼\alpha^{*}).

While our theory holds true for linear models, we believe that it provides accurate insight into the practical generalization abilities of LG-FedAvg, where we use deep networks and treat Î±ğ›¼\alpha as the split of the layers of between the local and global models. Empirically, we compare FigureÂ 2(a)-(b) (test error for linear models using Î±ğ›¼\alpha-interpolation on synthetic data) with FigureÂ 2(d) (test accuracy for deep networks using Î±ğ›¼\alpha-split on real-world mobile data). The close similarity implies that our theoretical analysis captures the correct relationship between local and global models.

5 Experiments

We evaluate how our method 1) verifies our theory under different data and device variances, 2) efficiently reduces parameters while retaining performance, 3) learns personalized models and handles data from heterogeneous sources, two settings with particularly high device variance, and 4) learns fair local representations that obfuscate private attributes. Code is included in the supplementary. Implementation details and sensitivity reports across hyperparameters are provided in AppendixÂ C.

5.1 Verifying Theoretical Analysis

Synthetic Data: We first experiment on synthetic data to verify our theoretical analysis on ensembling local and global models. Data on device mğ‘šm is generated by ğ±âˆ¼ğ’°â€‹[âˆ’1.0,1.0]similar-toğ±ğ’°1.01.0\mathbf{x}\sim\mathcal{U}[-1.0,1.0] and teacher weights ğ®m=ğ¯+ğ«msubscriptğ®ğ‘šğ¯subscriptğ«ğ‘š\mathbf{u}_{m}=\mathbf{v}+\mathbf{r}_{m} are sampled as ğ¯âˆ¼ğ’°â€‹[0.0,1.0]similar-toğ¯ğ’°0.01.0\mathbf{v}\sim\mathcal{U}[0.0,1.0], ğ«mâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ğŸd,Ï2â€‹ğˆd)similar-tosubscriptğ«ğ‘šğ’©subscript0ğ‘‘superscriptğœŒ2subscriptğˆğ‘‘\mathbf{r}_{m}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0}_{d},\rho^{2}\mathbf{I}_{d}), where Ï2superscriptğœŒ2\rho^{2} represents device variance. Labels are observed with noise, y=ğ®mâŠ¤â€‹ğ±+Ïµğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘štopğ±italic-Ïµy=\mathbf{u}_{m}^{\top}\mathbf{x}+\epsilon, Ïµâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2)similar-toitalic-Ïµğ’©0superscriptğœ2\epsilon\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}), where Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} represents data variance. We plot the average test error when local models perform better due to higher device variance (FigureÂ 2(a), Ïƒ=1.5,Ï=0.1formulae-sequenceğœ1.5ğœŒ0.1\sigma=1.5,\rho=0.1) and when global models perform better due to lower device variance (FigureÂ 2(b), Ïƒ=1.5,Ï=0.06formulae-sequenceğœ1.5ğœŒ0.06\sigma=1.5,\rho=0.06). In AppendixÂ C.1, we discuss the performance of LG-FedAvgÂ under several other variance settings. For all settings, using an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-interpolation of both local and global models performs either close to the optimal extremes or better than either extreme.

CIFAR-10: Next, we verify our theory on deep networks over complex image classification problems using CIFAR-10. We focus on a highly non-i.i.d. setting and follow the experimental design inÂ [38] by assigning examples from at most sâˆˆ{2,3,4,5,10}ğ‘ 234510s\in\{2,3,4,5,10\} classes to each device. The value of sğ‘ s simulates device variance: s=2ğ‘ 2s=2 represents highest device variance while s=10ğ‘ 10s=10 represents an i.i.d. split of labels to devices. From FigureÂ 2(c), we observe that LG-FedAvgÂ consistently outperforms local only and FedAvg. The performance gap is higher as device variance increases, which supports our theory that local models deal with high device variance.

5.2 Model Performance & Communication Efficiency

CIFAR-10: We compare our approach with existing federated learning methods with respect to model performance and communication. We randomly assign each device to examples of two classes (highly unbalanced). We consider two settings during testing: 1) Local Test, where we know which device the data belongs to (i.e. new predictions on an existing device) and choose that particular trained local model. For this setting, we split each deviceâ€™s data into train, validation, and test data, similar toÂ [50]. 2) New Test, in which we do not know which device the data belongs to (i.e. new predictions on new devices)Â [38], so we use an ensemble approach by averaging all trained local model logits before choosing the most likely classÂ [6]. For ensembling, all local model weights are sent to the server only once and averaged. We include this parameter exchange step and still show substantial communication improvement. We find that averaging model weights performs similarly (0.5%percent0.50.5\% for CIFAR) to averaging model outputs since deep ReLU nets are mostly linear). We choose LeNet-5Â [28] as our base model and we compare 4 methods: 1) FedAvgÂ [38] which is the traditional federated learning approach, 2) Local onlyÂ [50] as an extreme setting with only local models, 3) MTLÂ [50] which trains local models with parameter sharing in a multi-task fashion, and 4) LG-FedAvgÂ which is our proposed method with local and global models.

The results in TableÂ 1 show that LG-FedAvgÂ gives strong performance with low communication cost. For CIFAR local test, LG-FedAvgÂ significantly outperforms FedAvgÂ since local models allow us to better model the local device data distribution. For new test, LG-FedAvgÂ achieves similar performance to FedAvgÂ while using around 50%percent5050\% of the total parameters, and better performance with the same number of parameters. LG-FedAvgÂ also outperforms using local models only and local models trained with multitask learning (MTL). This shows that our end-to-end training strategy for local and global models is particularly suitable for large neural networks. We show MNIST results and sensitivity analysis wrt data and model splits in AppendixÂ C.2 and find similar observations.

Visual Question Answering (VQA): VQA is a large-scale multimodal benchmark with 0.250.250.25M images, 0.760.760.76M questions, and 101010M answersÂ [1]. We split the dataset in a non-i.i.d. manner and evaluate the accuracy under the local test setting. We use LSTMÂ [23] and ResNet-18Â [22] unimodal encoders as our local models and a global model which performs early fusionÂ [32] of text and image features for answer prediction. In Table 2, we observe that LG-FedAvgÂ reaches a goal accuracy of 40%percent4040\% while requiring lower communication costs (more VQA results and details in AppendixÂ C.2.3).

5.3 Learning Personalized Mood Predictors from Mobile Data

Data: We designed and collected a new dataset, Mobile Assessment for the Prediction of Suicide (MAPS), to determine real-time indicators of suicide risk in adolescents aged 13âˆ’18131813-18 years. This study monitors 100100100 adolescents including individuals who have recently attempted suicide, individuals who experience suicidal ideation, and psychiatric controls. Across a duration of 666 months, data was collected from each participantâ€™s smartphone using a keyboard logger which tracks all typed words. Participants were asked to rate their mood for the previous day on a scale ranging from 1âˆ’10011001-100, with higher scores indicating a better mood. All users have given consent for their mobile device data to be collected and shared with us for research purposes. MAPS is a realistic federated learning benchmark since it contains real-world data with privacy concerns and high device variance due to highly personalized use of mobile phones. We used a preliminary preprocessed version containing 572572572 samples across 141414 participants. We discretize the scores into 555 bins for 555-way classification. We use a random 80/10/1080101080/10/10 split for training/validation/testing, conduct all experiments 101010 times, and report the average accuracy and standard deviation (details in AppendixÂ C.3).

Models: To assess how mobile text data can be used to make personalized mood predictions, we train a MLP classifier on top of a Bi-LSTM encoder on word embeddings. In addition to local only and FedAvg, we test LG-FedAvgÂ across different splits of local and global model layers (i.e. Î±âˆˆ{0.2,0.4,0.6,0.8}ğ›¼0.20.40.60.8\alpha\in\{0.2,0.4,0.6,0.8\}) while keeping the total parameter count constant.

Results: From FigureÂ 2(d), consistent with our theoretical findings, an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-split across local and global models leverages both personalized representations per devices as well as statistical strength sharing through data across all devices, outperforming either local or global extremes.

5.4 Heterogeneous Data in an Online Setting

Data: We test whether LG-FedAvgÂ can handle heterogeneous data from a new source introduced during testing. We split MNIST across 100100100 devices in both an i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. setting, then introduce a new device with 3,00030003,000 training and 500500500 test MNIST examples but rotated 909090 degrees. This simulates a drastic change in the data distribution.

Models: We consider 3 methods: 1) FedAvg, 2) FedProxÂ [30]: a method designed specifically for heterogeneous data by regularizing the local updates to reduce overfitting to local devices, and 3) LG-FedAvg: train on the original 100100100 devices, and when a new device comes, learn local representations before fine-tuning the global model. We hypothesize that good local models can â€œunrotateâ€ images from the new device to better match the data distribution seen by the global model. When learning on the new device, we also retrain on a fraction Cğ¶C of the original devices: C=0.0ğ¶0.0C=0.0 implies no fine-tuning and C=0.1ğ¶0.1C=0.1 implies some fine-tuning (C=1.0ğ¶1.0C=1.0 implies retraining on all data which is impractical).

Results: We report results in TableÂ 3 and observe that: 1) FedAvgÂ suffers from catastrophic forgettingÂ [48] without fine-tuning (C=0.0ğ¶0.0C=0.0), in which the global model can perform well on the new deviceâ€™s rotated MNIST (92%)percent92(92\%) but completely forgets how to classify regular MNIST (32%)percent32(32\%). Only after fine-tuning (C=0.1ğ¶0.1C=0.1) does the performance on both regular and rotated MNIST improve, but this requires more communication over the 100100100 devices. 2) LG-FedAvgÂ with local models relieves catastrophic forgetting. Augmenting local models indeed helps to improve online performance on rotated MNIST (93%)percent93(93\%) while allowing the global model to retain performance on regular MNIST (97%)percent97(97\%), outperforming both FedAvgÂ and FedProx. We believe LG-FedAvgÂ achieves these results by learning a strong local representation that requires fewer updates from the trained global model.

5.5 Learning Fair Representations

Data: We examine whether local models can be trained to protect private attributes from the global model. We use the UCI adult datasetÂ [24] to predict whether an individual makes more than 505050K per year based on their personal attributes. However, we want our models to be invariant to the sensitive attributes of race and gender instead of picking up on correlations that could exacerbate biases.

Models: We adapt adversarial learning to remove protected attributes from local models (see AppendixÂ B.1. Specifically, we aim to learn fair local representations from which a fully trained adversarial network should not be able to predict the protected attributes. We report three methods: 1) FedAvgÂ with only a global model and global adversary both updated using FedAvg. The global model is not trained with the adversarial loss since it is simply not possible: once local device data passes through the global model, privacy is potentially violated. 2) LG-FedAvgÂ without penalizing the adversarial network, and 3) LG-FedAvg++Adv which jointly trains local, global, and adversary models to learn fair local representations before global prediction.

Results: We report results according to: 1) classifier binary accuracy, 2) classifier ROC AUC score, and 3) adversary ROC AUC score. The classifier metrics should be as close to 100%percent100100\% as possible while the adversary should be as close to 50%percent5050\% as possible. From TableÂ 4, LG-FedAvg++Adv learns fair local representations that are unable to predict protected attributes (âˆ¼50%similar-toabsentpercent50\sim 50\% adversary AUC) with only a small drop in global accuracy (âˆ¼4%)similar-toabsentpercent4(\sim 4\%). In order to ensure that poor adversary AUC was indeed due to fair representations instead of a poorly trained adversary, we train a post-fit classifier from local representations to protected attributes and achieve similar random results.

6 Conclusion

We proposed LG-FedAvgÂ combining local representation learning with federated training of global models. Our theoretical analysis shows that an ensemble of local and global models reduces both data variance and device variance. On a suite of real-world datasets, LG-FedAvgÂ achieves strong performance while reducing communication costs, learns personalized models, better deals with heterogeneous data, and effectively learns fair representations that obfuscate protected attributes.

Broader Impacts

Federated learning provides tools for large-scale distributed training at unprecedented scales but at the same time requires more research on its implications to society and policy.

Broader applications: By 2025, it is estimated that there will be more than to 75 billion IoT (Internet of Things) devices all connected to the internet and sharing data with each otherÂ [51]. Organizing, processing, and learning from device data will use federated learning techniques. It has already been shown to be a promising approach for applications such as learning the social activities of mobile phone users, early forecasting of health events like heart attack risks from wearable devices, and localization of pedestrians for autonomous vehiclesÂ [29]. The societal impacts revolving around more invasive federated learning technologies have to be taken into account as we design future systems that increasingly leverage distributed mobile data.

Applications in mental health: Suicide is the second leading cause of death among adolescents. In addition to deaths, 16% of high school students report seriously considering suicide each year, and 8% make one or more suicide attempts (CDC, 2015). Despite these alarming statistics, there is little consensus concerning imminent risk for suicideÂ [18, 26]. Given the impact of suicide on society, there is an urgent need to better understand the behavior markers related to suicidal ideation.

â€œJust-in-timeâ€ adaptive interventions delivered via mobile health applications provide a platform of exciting developments in low-intensity, high-impact interventionsÂ [43]. The ability to intervene precisely during an acute risk for suicide could dramatically reduce the loss of life. To realize this goal, we need accurate and timely methods that predict when interventions are most needed. Federated learning is particularly useful in monitoring (with participantsâ€™ permission) mobile data to assess mental health and provide early interventions. Our data collection, experimental study, and computational approaches provide a step towards data intensive longitudinal monitoring of human behavior. However, one must take care to summarize behaviors from mobile data without identifying the user through personal (e.g., personally identifiable information) or protected attributes (e.g., race, gender). This form of anonymity is critical when implementing these suicide detection technologies in real-world scenarios. Our goal is to be highly predictive of STBs while remaining as privacy-preserving as possible. We outline some of the potential privacy and security concerns below and show some possibilities brought about from the flexibility of our local models.

Privacy: There are privacy risks associated with making predictions from mobile data. Although federated learning only keeps data private on each device without sending it to other locations, the presence of oneâ€™s data during distributed model training will likely affect model predictions. Therefore it is crucial to obtain user consent before collecting device data. In our experiments with real-world mobile data, all participants have given consent for their mobile device data to be collected and shared with us for research purposes. All data was anonymized and stripped of all personal (e.g., personally identifiable information) and protected attributes (e.g., race, gender).

Security: Communicating model updates throughout the training process could possibly reveal sensitive information, either to a third-party, or to the central server. Federated learning is also particularly sensitive to external security attacks from adversariesÂ [36]. Recent methods to increase the security of federated learning systems come at the cost of reduced performance or efficiency. We believe that our proposed local-global models make federated learning more interpretable and flexible since local models can be appropriately adjusted to be more secure. However, there is a lot more work to be done in these directions, starting by accurately quantifying the trade-offs between security, privacy and performance in federated learningÂ [29].

Social biases: We acknowledge that there is a risk of exposure bias due to imbalanced datasets, especially when personal mobile data is involved. Models trained on biased data have been shown to amplify the underlying social biases especially when they correlate with the prediction targetsÂ [34]. Our experiment showcased one example of maintaining fairness via adversarial training, but leaves room for future work in exploring other methods tailored for specific scenarios (e.g. debiasing wordsÂ [4], sentencesÂ [31], and imagesÂ [46]). These methods can be easily applied to local representations before input into the global model. Future research should also focus on quantifying the trade-offs between bias and performanceÂ [58].

Overall, we believe that our proposed approach can help quantify the tradeoffs between local and global models regarding performance, communication, privacy, security, and fairness. Its flexibility also offers several exciting directions of future work in ensuring privacy and fairness of local representations. We hope that this brings about future opportunities for large-scale real-time analytics in healthcare and transportation using federated learning.

Appendix

Appendix A Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we restate our main results and provide details proofs for them. We start with the short comment that, for the federated linear regression problem we are solving, gradient descent converges to the same solution as the commonly used ridgeless linear regression solution, as is shown in [21]. This means that ğ®^^ğ®\hat{\mathbf{u}} converges to ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} and ğ¯^^ğ¯\hat{\mathbf{v}} converges to ğ¯ğ¯\mathbf{v} in expectation. We also assume in our analysis that dNğ‘‘ğ‘\frac{d}{N} is small and can be summarized in the big-Oğ‘‚O notation; however, this does not mean that the term dNâ€‹Ïƒ2ğ‘‘ğ‘superscriptğœ2\frac{d}{N}\sigma^{2} is small because the noise present in the dataset might be a function of Nğ‘N. For example, in the well-studied label noise literature, the noise rate Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is often proportional to Nğ‘N, cancelling out the Nğ‘N term in the denominatorÂ [61]. In practice, this happens when the dataset has a fixed probability of wrong labels.

A.1 Analysis of Federated Learning Baselines

We begin by analyzing two baselines for federated learning.

The first method learns local models on each deviceÂ [50]: fâ„“â€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^,ğ®^m)=fâ€‹(ğ±;ğ®^m)=ğ®^mâŠ¤â€‹ğ±subscriptğ‘“â„“ğ±^ğ¯subscript^ğ®ğ‘šğ‘“ğ±subscript^ğ®ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscript^ğ®ğ‘štopğ±f_{\ell}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}},\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m})=f(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m})=\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m}^{\top}\mathbf{x}.

Proposition 1.

The generalization error â„°â€‹(fâ„“)â„°subscriptğ‘“â„“\mathcal{E}(f_{\ell}) of local model fâ„“â€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^,ğ®^m)subscriptğ‘“â„“ğ±^ğ¯subscript^ğ®ğ‘šf_{\ell}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}},\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m}) is dNâ€‹Ïƒ2ğ‘‘ğ‘superscriptğœ2\frac{d}{N}\sigma^{2}.

Proof.

Similarly, set Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 in equationÂ 18 of corollaryÂ  â€£ A and we obtain that â„°â€‹(fâ„“)=Varâ€‹[fğ®^]=dNâ€‹Ïƒ2â„°subscriptğ‘“â„“Vardelimited-[]subscriptğ‘“^ğ®ğ‘‘ğ‘superscriptğœ2\mathcal{E}(f_{\ell})=\text{Var}[f_{\hat{\mathbf{u}}}]=\frac{d}{N}\sigma^{2}. âˆ

This shows that local models only control data variance at a rate of d/Nğ‘‘ğ‘d/{N} since they are only updated using local device data which may be limited in number and vary highly (both in quality and quantity) across devices. However, local models do not suffer from device variance.

The second method updates a joint global modelÂ [38], which is equivalent to setting Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 in our previous analysis, i.e. fgâ€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^,ğ®^m)=fâ€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^)=ğ¯^âŠ¤â€‹ğ±subscriptğ‘“ğ‘”ğ±^ğ¯subscript^ğ®ğ‘šğ‘“ğ±^ğ¯superscript^ğ¯topğ±f_{g}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}},\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m})=f(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}})=\hat{\mathbf{v}}^{\top}\mathbf{x}. We can compute its generalization error:

Proposition 2.

The generalization error â„°â€‹(fg)â„°subscriptğ‘“ğ‘”\mathcal{E}(f_{g}) of the global model fgâ€‹(ğ±;ğ¯^,ğ®^m)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘”ğ±^ğ¯subscript^ğ®ğ‘šf_{g}(\mathbf{x};\hat{\mathbf{v}},\hat{\mathbf{u}}_{m}) is Mâˆ’1Mâ€‹Ï2+dMâ€‹Nâ€‹Ïƒ2ğ‘€1ğ‘€superscriptğœŒ2ğ‘‘ğ‘€ğ‘superscriptğœ2\frac{M-1}{M}\rho^{2}+\frac{d}{MN}\sigma^{2}.

Therefore, global models are able to control for data variance (Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}) at a rate of d/(Mâ€‹N)ğ‘‘ğ‘€ğ‘d/(MN), decreasing with the total number of datapoints across all devices (since global parameters are updated using data across all devices), which is better than the rate for local models. However, it suffers from an extra Oâ€‹(Ï2)ğ‘‚superscriptğœŒ2O(\rho^{2}) term representing device variance so one global model is unable to account for very different devices.

âˆ

This shows that using an ensemble of local and global models reduces both data variance and device variance. When Ï2superscriptğœŒ2\rho^{2} is large (high device variance), one should lean towards using local models that better model the local data distributions (larger Î±âˆ—superscriptğ›¼\alpha^{*}). Conversely, when Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is large (high data variance), one should lean towards using a global model whose parameters are updated using more data across all devices (smaller Î±âˆ—superscriptğ›¼\alpha^{*}).

Appendix B Fair Representation Learning

B.1 Fair Training of Local Models

In this section we detail one extension of local representation learning to remove information that might be indicative of protected attributes. The data on each device is now a triple (ğ—m,ğ˜m,ğm)subscriptğ—ğ‘šsubscriptğ˜ğ‘šsubscriptğğ‘š(\mathbf{X}_{m},\mathbf{Y}_{m},\mathbf{P}_{m}) drawn non-i.i.d. from a joint distribution pâ€‹(X,Y,P)ğ‘ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘ƒp(X,Y,P) where ğ©âˆˆğ’«ğ©ğ’«\mathbf{p}\in\mathcal{P} are some protected attributes which the model should not predict. For example, although there exist correlations between race and incomeÂ [27] which could help in income predictionÂ [10], it would be undesirable for our models to rely on these correlations since these would exacerbate racial biases.

To learn fair local representations, we use adversarial trainingÂ [35] to remove protected attributes (FigureÂ 1 (d)). More formally, we aim to learn a local model â„“msubscriptâ„“ğ‘š\ell_{m} such that the distribution of â„“mâ€‹(ğ±;Î¸mâ„“)subscriptâ„“ğ‘šğ±superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“\ell_{m}(\mathbf{x};\theta_{m}^{\ell}) conditional on ğ¡ğ¡\mathbf{h} is invariant with respect to protected attributes ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}:

pâ€‹(â„“mâ€‹(ğ±;Î¸mâ„“)=ğ¡|ğ©)=pâ€‹(â„“mâ€‹(ğ±;Î¸mâ„“)=ğ¡|ğ©â€²)ğ‘subscriptâ„“ğ‘šğ±superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“conditionalğ¡ğ©ğ‘subscriptâ„“ğ‘šğ±superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“conditionalğ¡superscriptğ©â€²p(\ell_{m}(\mathbf{x};\theta_{m}^{\ell})=\mathbf{h}|\mathbf{p})=p(\ell_{m}(\mathbf{x};\theta_{m}^{\ell})=\mathbf{h}|\mathbf{p}^{\prime}) (39)

for all ğ©,ğ©â€²âˆˆğ’«ğ©superscriptğ©â€²ğ’«\mathbf{p},\mathbf{p}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{P} and outputs ğ¡âˆˆâ„‹ğ¡â„‹\mathbf{h}\in{\cal H} of â„“mâ€‹(â‹…;Î¸mâ„“)subscriptâ„“ğ‘šâ‹…superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“\ell_{m}(\ \cdot\ ;\theta_{m}^{\ell}), thereby implying that â„“mâ€‹(ğ±;Î¸mâ„“)subscriptâ„“ğ‘šğ±superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“\ell_{m}(\mathbf{x};\theta_{m}^{\ell}) and ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p} are independent.Â [35] showed that we can use adversarial networks in order to constrain model â„“msubscriptâ„“ğ‘š\ell_{m} to satisfy EquationÂ (39). â„“msubscriptâ„“ğ‘š\ell_{m} is pit against an auxiliary adversarial model am=pÎ¸maâ€‹(ğ©|fâ€‹(ğ±;Î¸mâ„“)=ğ¡)subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘conditionalğ©ğ‘“ğ±superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“ğ¡a_{m}=p_{\theta_{m}^{a}}(\mathbf{p}|f(\mathbf{x};\theta_{m}^{\ell})=\mathbf{h}) with parameters Î¸masuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘\theta_{m}^{a} and loss â„’maâ€‹(Î¸mâ„“,Î¸ma)superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘{\cal L}_{m}^{a}(\theta_{m}^{\ell},\theta_{m}^{a}). If pâ€‹(â„“mâ€‹(ğ±;Î¸mâ„“)=ğ¡|ğ©)ğ‘subscriptâ„“ğ‘šğ±superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“conditionalğ¡ğ©p(\ell_{m}(\mathbf{x};\theta_{m}^{\ell})=\mathbf{h}|\mathbf{p}) varies with ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p}, then the corresponding correlation can be captured by adversary amsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ša_{m}. Therefore, we train â„“msubscriptâ„“ğ‘š\ell_{m} to both minimize the global prediction loss â„’mgâ€‹(Î¸mâ„“,Î¸ma)superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘\mathcal{L}_{m}^{g}(\theta_{m}^{\ell},\theta_{m}^{a}) and to maximize the adversarial loss â„’maâ€‹(Î¸mâ„“,Î¸ma)superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šâ„“superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘šğ‘{\cal L}_{m}^{a}(\theta_{m}^{\ell},\theta_{m}^{a}). In practice, the local model â„“msubscriptâ„“ğ‘š\ell_{m}, (local copy of the) global model gğ‘”g, and adversarial model amsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ša_{m} are updated by solving for the minimax solution:

PropositionÂ 3 in AppendixÂ A further shows that adversarial training learns an optimal local model â„“msubscriptâ„“ğ‘š\ell_{m} that is invariant with respect to ğ©ğ©\mathbf{p} under local device data distribution pâ€‹(Xm,Ym,Pm)ğ‘subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šp(X_{m},Y_{m},P_{m}). To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to extend this analysis, both theoretically and empirically, to the federated learning setting. Key to this analysis is the separation of local and global models which allows learning of fair intermediate representations ğ¡ğ¡\mathbf{h}.

In FigureÂ 1, we also illustrate several other choices of local representation learning using auxiliary local models amsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ša_{m} for (b) unsupervised autoencoding training, where amsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ša_{m} reconstructs ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} given ğ¡ğ¡\mathbf{h}, and (c) self-supervised learning (e.g. jigsaw solvingÂ [45]), where amsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ša_{m} predicts auxiliary features ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z} given ğ¡ğ¡\mathbf{h}. However, when using local supervised learning, amsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ša_{m} and gğ‘”g are similar classification branches (FigureÂ 1 (a)) both supervised by the target labels. LG-FedAvgÂ can therefore be trained without amsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ša_{m} to directly learn local representations ğ¡ğ¡\mathbf{h} for the global model gğ‘”g to make predictions (equationÂ 1). Thus, LG-FedAvgÂ for supervised learning does not incur additional computational complexity while reducing communicated global parameters.

Appendix C Experimental Details and Extra Results

Here we provide all the details regarding experimental setup, dataset preprocessing, model architectures, model training, and performance evaluation. Our anonymized code is attached in the supplementary material. All experiments are conducted on a single machine with 4 GeForce GTX TITAN X GPUs.

A note on hyperparameters used: For MNIST and CIFAR experiments, we would like to emphasize that our initial set of hyperparameters were taken directly from the default set of hyperparamters in https://github.com/shaoxiongji/federated-learning for fair comparison across all baselines and our approach. They were NOT manually tuned for LG-FedAvgÂ to perform better.

For synthetic data, there are no hyperparamters involved.

For experiments on mobile data, since it is a new dataset, we start by training the best vanilla federated learning model using FedAvgÂ and use the exact same set of hyperparameters for LG-FedAvg.

For experiments on fairness, we again use all the default hyperparameters as obtained from the tutorial https://blog.godatadriven.com/fairness-in-ml and associated code https://github.com/equialgo/fairness-in-ml.

C.3 Learning Personalized Mood Predictors from Mobile Data

Dataset details: We designed and collected a new dataset called Mobile Assessment for the Prediction of Suicide (MAPS). MAPS was designed to elucidate real-time indicators of suicide risk in adolescents ages 13âˆ’18131813-18 years. Current adolescent suicide ideators and recent suicide attempters along with aged-matched psychiatric controls with no lifetime suicidal thoughts and behaviors completed baseline clinical assessments (i.e., lifetime mental disorders, current psychiatric symptoms). Following the baseline clinical characterization, a smartphone app, the Effortless Assessment of Risk States (EARS), was installed onto adolescentsâ€™ phones, and passive sensor data were acquired for 666-months. Notably, during EARS installation, a keyboard logger is configured on adolescentsâ€™ phones, which then tracks all words typed into the phone as well as they app used during this period. Each day during the 666-month follow-up, participants also were asked to rate their mood on the previous day on a scale ranging from 1âˆ’10011001-100, with higher scores indicating a better mood.

All users have given consent for their mobile device data to be collected and shared with us for research purposes.

MAPS is a realistic federated learning benchmark since it contains real-world data with privacy concerns and high device variance due to highly personalized use of mobile phones. We used a preliminary preprocessed version containing 572572572 samples across 141414 participants. We discretize the scores into 555 bins for 555-way classification. We use a random 80/10/1080101080/10/10 split for training/validation/testing, conduct all experiments 101010 times, and report the average accuracy and standard deviation.

Model details: To assess how mobile text data can be used to make personalized mood predictions, we train a MLP classifier on top of a Bi-LSTM encoder. The Bi-LSTM has 128 hidden units and the MLP has two hidden layers, each with size 512. We conduct our experiments over 10 iterations. Within each iteration, we use a random 80/10/10 split for training/validation/testing. We train and validate our model 5 times on this split and select the model that performs best on the validation set. We use the test accuracy of this best-performing model as the test accuracy for the iteration. We report the average accuracy and standard deviation over all 10 iterations in FigureÂ 2(d). In addition to local only and FedAvgÂ results, we plot the performance of LG-FedAvgÂ across different splits of local and global models (i.e. Î±âˆˆ{0.2,0.4,0.6,0.8}ğ›¼0.20.40.60.8\alpha\in\{0.2,0.4,0.6,0.8\}). Consistent with our theoretical findings, an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-split across local and global models leverages both personalized representations per devices as well as statistical strength sharing through data across all devices, outperforming either local or global extremes.

However, we include an additional device, which randomly samples 3000 and 500 images from the train and test sets respectively and rotates them by a fixed 90 degrees. C.5 Learning Fair Representations

Details: For method 1, FedAvg, we train the global model and global adversary for 505050 outer epochs, within which the number of local epochs E=10ğ¸10E=10. For methods 2 and 3 involving local models, we begin by pre-training the local models and local adversaries for 101010 epochs before joint local and global training for 10 epochs. TableÂ 11 shows the table of all hyperparameters used. Experiments were run 10 times with the same hyperparameters but different random seeds. We aimed to keep the local, global, and adversary models as similar as possible between the three baselines for fair comparison. Apart from the number of local and global epochs all hyperparameters were kept the same from the tutorial https://blog.godatadriven.com/fairness-in-ml and associated code https://github.com/equialgo/fairness-in-ml. The data can be found at https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Adult.

Appendix D Discussion and Future Work

We believe that LG-FedAvgÂ is a general approach that offers several extensions for future work.

Firstly, combining LG-FedAvgÂ with existing work on compressing the number of parameters and gradient updates could further improve the efficiency of federated learning. For example, existing work in sparsifying the data and modelÂ [54], developing efficient gradient-based methodsÂ [55, 12], and compressing the updatesÂ [53, 60, 33] can all be applied to our local and global models. In particular, sparsifying the model through techniques such as distillationÂ [47] and hashingÂ [11] could help to store the local models on devices with small memory and computational power.

Secondly, depending on the test time scenario (i.e. local test vs new test), there is a trade off between the ideal size of local models and the global model. If we know which device the test data belongs to, then having a more accurate local model would allow us to perform better prediction at test time. However, if we do not know which device the test data belongs to, it is important to use a more accurate global model to learn the true data distribution across all devices. Therefore, another step for future work would be dynamically learn the number of layers spread across the local and the global models, in a manner similar to learning dynamic computation steps in neural networksÂ [5]. Different devices which contain different data distributions could use different local models which are dynamically learnt rather than hand-designed by the user. Techniques in neural architecture search could also be helpful for this purpose.

Finally, learning fair representations is of utmost importance as our machine learning systems are deployed in real-life settings such as healthcare, law, and policy-making. In addition to the adversarial training method we described in this paper, there are a variety of methods for learning fair representations that can also be incorporated into our flexible local models. For example, recent work has shown that pre-trained word and sentence representations encode and exacerbate gender, race, and religious biasesÂ [4, 37, 59]. Incorporating these debiasing methods for text data would be an important step towards learning fair and unbiased local representations in federated learning.
